Absent from most international visitors' itineraries, Caldas da Rainha is an excellent place to experience daily life in Portugal without hordes of tourists.

Caldas da Rainha has two primary claims to fame: its curative sulfurous waters and its whimsical decorative pottery.

Caldas da Rainha was founded by Queen Leonor, wife of King João II. One day in 1484, while traveling from Óbidos to Batalha, she found a group of peasants bathing in foul-smelling waters by the roadside. She stopped to inquire about this oddity and was told that the waters possessed curative powers. She decided to try them for herself. She was pleased to find that she was quickly relieved of some affliction she had been suffering (exactly what is not known). On that site, the queen ordered a thermal hospital built so that others may enjoy the relief that she felt. The spa hospital still stands to serve those with certain medical conditions.

Caldas da Rainha is an artistic city. You can find works of art throughout the city, and not just in its several museums. Sculptures serve as centerpieces to most of the city's traffic circles. Caldas's main park contains many statues and sculptures. The city is home to a college of art and design, as well as a vocational school devoted to ceramics. Caldas's historical center hosts many lovely buildings, with many examples of Art Nouveau style.

Caldas da Rainha is a compact city. Most locations of interest are within 10–15 min walking. Although Caldas is in a hilly region, most of the hills within the city are manageable by people of moderate fitness.

Taxis in Caldas da Rainha have a creamy beige color. Other jurisdictions may have black taxis with a minty green roof. There are two taxi stands in the city: Rua Engenheiro Duarte Pacheco (+351 262 831 098) and Praça da República (+351 262 832 455). If you are not at either location, call the number for either and the next available taxi will come pick you up.

Caldas da Rainha offers many opportunities for shopping. The center of town has several streets lined with stores, many of which are mom-and-pop shops, with a smattering of chains. Main shopping streets include Rua dos Heróis da Grande Guerra, Rua Almirante Cândido dos Reis (also known as Rua das Montras), Rua da Liberdade, and various surrounding streets.

If you buy any souvenirs in Caldas, you should buy some of the famous local pottery, which comes in two basic varieties. The factory of Rafael Bordallo Pinheiro produces many decorative and useful pieces shaped like fruits and vegetables. Perhaps the most popular of these pieces are cabbage-shaped tureens and platters. The second broad variety is purely decorative. Most famous among these are the phalluses of Caldas, which like the real thing come in various sizes and can be found all over town.
